para.paratext: Since 1971, Georgia has been making the authentication of records from hospitals and other medical institutions easier. The statute under the new Code is like its predecessor, former O.C.G.A. § 24-7-9, but it expands the types of medical bills that may be introduced into evidence.
O.C.G.A. § 24-9-921, “Competency to identify medical bills,” states:

(a) Upon the trial of any civil proceeding involving injury or disease, the patient or the member of his or her family or other person responsible for the care of the patient shall be a competent witness to identify bills for expenses incurred in the treatment of the patient upon a showing by such a witness that the expenses were incurred in connection with the treatment of the injury, disease, or disability involved in the subject of litigation at trial and that the bills were received from:
A pharmacy, drugstore, or supplier of therapeutic or orthopedic devices; or

A licensed practicing physician, dentist, orthodontist, podiatrist, physical or occupational therapist, doctor of chiropractic, psychologist, advanced practice registered nurse, social worker, professional counselor, or marriage and family therapist.

(b) Such items of evidence need not be identified by the one who submits the bill, and it shall not be necessary for an expert witness to testify that the charges were reasonable and necessary. However, nothing in this Code section shall be construed to limit the right of a thorough and sifting cross-examination as to such items of evidence.
The Georgia Court of Appeals held in Davis v. Pachuilo[1] that the patient could properly identify medical bills even though they had been mailed to his employer.
In Wilson v. Childers,[2] the court held that a hospital's acting custodian could certify a copy of a lab report and the personnel who prepared the report need not testify.
Even when evidence is authenticated under the statute, it is still necessary to show that the medical expense was in connection with the condition involved in the litigation on trial.[3]

In Emory Healthcare, Inc. v. Pardue,[4] the daughter of a patient was permitted to tender medical bills regarding her mother's care and to testify that she had deleted from the bills any treatment not related to the underlying action.
Davis v. Pachuilo, 169 Ga. App. 677, 314 S.E.2d 692 (1984).
Wilson v. Childers, 174 Ga. App. 179, 329 S.E.2d 503 (1985).

App. 516, 352 S.E.2d 832, 37 Ed. Law Rep. 720 (1987); Cheney v. Lawson, 333 Ga. App. 180, 773 S.E.2d 297 (2015).
